occurrences.line_text: Ensewing, made her knowen to him at last:
(Quoth he) knowes best the termes established;
And where he hits, nought knowes, & whom he hurts, nought cares.
That knowes her port, and thither sailes by ayme,
Out of her fruitfull lap; how, no man knowes,
That knowes no kinred, nor regardes no right,
The bird, that knowes not the false fowlers call,
And fortune Boteswaine no assuraunce knowes,
Franckly each paramour his leman knowes,
Poore Colin Clout (who knowes not Colin Clout?)
And sayd, Sith then thou knowest all our griefe,
Well knowing true all, that he did reherse,
And both of old well knowing by their names,
Knowing the miserie of their estate,
Well knowing her to be his deaths sole instrument.
Not knowing natures worke, nor what to weene,
Assayld, not knowing what to armes doth long.
Twixt life and death, not knowing what was donne.
Yet knowing that her Knight now neare did draw,
Knowing his voice although not heard long sin,
Yet knowing not, what meant that sodaine thro,
Knowing his fatall hand by former feare;
Shall he thy sins vp in his knowledge fold,
How euer list her now her knowledge faine,
Or knowledge of those woods, where he did dwell,
The lines of life, from liuing knowledge hid.
That out of all mens knowledge he was worne at last.
From peoples knowledge labour'd to concele.
For feare her mistresse shold haue knowledge gayned,
They both deformed, scarsely could be known.
Known by good markes, and perfect good espiall,
I saw before mine eyes, if I were knowne to stray.
Desird of forreine foemen to be knowne,
For he that made the same, was knowne right well
Is laid away, and counterfesaunce knowne.
Which knowne, and all that noyd his heauie spright
Her name was Mercie, well knowne ouer all,
Ne other to himselfe is knowne this day,
But with sharpe speare the rest made dearly knowne.
Foreby a narrow foord, to them well knowne,
His inward griefe, by meanes to him well knowne,
Depeincted was, full easie to be knowne,
Well knowne to appertaine to Florimell,
The shield and armes well knowne to be the same,
Though knowne to few, that Arthegall he hight,
But knowne by fame, and by an Hebene speare,
Had knowne right well with colourd ribbands drest:
Were cowards knowne, and litle count did hold,
No warre was knowne, no dreadfull trompets sound,
So did the Ladies both, as may be knowne,
And by what markes may he be knowne againe?
Being the dowry of his wife well knowne,
Well knowne, and far renowmed heretofore,
And for what cause, tell if thou haue it knowne.
The gentle minde by gentle deeds is knowne.
That it became a famous knight well knowne,
Vnwilling to be knowne, or seene at all,
But by all meanes the daunger knowne did shonne:
And closely did her wed, but knowne to few.
Well know'st thou, whe[n] we friendship first did sweare,
Fierce Eryx, and Alebius that know'th
Abhorred Murder, who with bloudie knyfe
They all were fled for feare, but whether, nether kond.
Time and suffised fates to former kynd
Doe life conceiue and quickned are by kynd:
Them found all three according to their kynd:
That she a Queene, and come of Princely kynd,
The fayrest kyne aliue, but of the fiercest kynd.
Agreeing in bad will and cancred kynd,
A voice, that seemed of some woman kynd,
And at the last breake forth in his owne proper kynd.
In such a saluage wight, of brutish kynd,
To goe about to salue such kynd of sore,
Whether such grace were giuen her by kynd,
The sonne of Venus who is myld by kynd,
As when Latonaes daughter cruell kynde,
And as ye soft and tender are by kynde,
A monstrous cruelty gainst course of kynde.
As comely carriage, entertainement kynde,
They teach vs, how to each degree and kynde
She yet forgets, that she of men was kynded:
In th'end his kyndly courtesie to proue,
From that day forth he kyndnesse to her showed,
Arryuing, to his kyne for food assynd;
The fayrest kyne aliue, but of the fiercest kynd.
The foolish Kyte, led with licentious will,
Now needeth him no lenger labour spend,
But when he saw his labour all was vaine,
She backe returned with some labour lost;
Against an hill, ne might from labour lin;
Did breed him endlesse labour to subdew:
Who when their powres, empaird through labour long,
To seeke her out with labour, and long tyne,
Feare, sicknesse, age, losse, labour, sorrow, strife,
Did labour liuely to expresse the same,
A worke of labour long, and endlesse prayse:
Of death and labour lay, halfe dead, halfe quicke,
The knight him seeing labour so in vaine,
So lost his labour vaine and idle industry.
For sure it would deceiue thy labour, and thy might.
I labour would to guide you through all Faery land.
A labour huge, exceeding farre my might:
His sonne king Leill by fathers labour long,
But labour lost it was, to weene approch him neare.
And all his labour brought to happie end,
And thought his labour lost and trauell vaine,
Of that great chamber, should be labour lost:
When too huge toile and labour them constraines:
Them bound till his returne, their labour not to slake.
Of his long labour, he gan fowly wyte
Which seeme to labour vnder their fruits lode:
For both to be and seeme to him was labour lich.
To see his whole yeares labour lost so soone,
And with like labour walke the world around,
Great labour fondly hast thou hent in hand,
Thy labour all is lost, I greatly dread,
My labour adde, and be partaker of their speed.
Laught at his foolish labour spent in waste;
Then life and labour both in vaine to spend.
Through toylesome heate and labour of her weary fight.
Might not it peise; yet did he labour long,
By any skill or labour it would sit,
So from her parting, she thenceforth did labour
Giue him more labour, and with streighter law,
And by them long with carefull labour nurst,
But when the Saluage saw his labour vaine,
That this of all his labour and long paine
And wrought so well with labour and long paine,
Labour'd in vaine, to haue recur'd their prize,
But labour'd long in that deepe ford with vaine disease.
From peoples knowledge labour'd to concele.
And by the lilly hand her labour'd vp to reare.
Him selfe thereof he labour'd to acquite,
After that he had labourd long in vaine,
Had long while laboured it to engraue:
The other which was entred, laboured fast
Each labouring t'aduance the others gest,
Such were the labours of this Lady meeke,
And through long labours huntest after fame,
After long labours and aduentures spent,
After long paines and labours manifold,
And labours long, through which ye hither came,
But after labours long, and sad delay,
And hath for twelue huge labours high extold,
Whiles from their iournall labours they did rest,
After his trauell long, and labours manifold.
But who his limbs with labours, and his mind
Bid thee to them thy fruitlesse labours yield,
That may emongst Alcides labours stand.
To whom I leuell all my labours end,
In sewing deeds of armes, my liues and labours end.
Whom he through wearie wars and labours long,
Not caring his long labours to deface,
For many labours more, then I haue found,
That I thy labours lost may thus reuiue,
And bad them leaue their labours and long toyle,
And litle prays'd his labours euill speed,
In perils strange, in labours long and wide;
To guide mens labours, brought them also ease,
But on the labours of poore men to feed,
Amongst themselues, and did their labours share,
Or to present her with their labours late;
Faire Thyamis the daughter of Labryde,
And like to lead the labyrinth about;
Of his wide Labyrinth, and then to haue them dround.
False Labyrinthes, fond runners eyes to daze;
Them trebly breaded in a threefold lace,
Of Lincolne greene, belayd with siluer lace;
Was hangd on high with golden ribbands laced;
And mailes betweene, and laced close afore:
As yet not laced, nor her golden haire
From Lacedï¿½mon fetcht the fairest Dame,
By griesly Lachesis was spun with paine,
But Lachesis thereat gan to repine,
With loathly frogs and toades, which eyes did lacke,
Whose greedy lust did lacke in greatest store,
And could not lacke her louers company,
And of three furlongs does but litle lacke;
And grieu'd, so long to lacke his greedy pray;
Or doen you loue, or doen you lacke your will?
To be a beast, and lacke intelligence.
And lacke of reskewes will to parley driue;
And felt some ruth, or sence his hand did lacke,
Till that vneath they forced were for lacke
There gan he me to curse and ban, for lacke
Be lacke of children, to supply your place,
Of that same Monster late, for lacke of heed,
That both thy loue, for lacke of hardiment,
Yet fearing death, and next to death the lacke
And this sweet peace, whose lacke did then appeare.
Tell, me what were they all, whose lacke thee grieues so sore.
And weeping said, Ah my long lacked Lord,
Who when as now long time he lacked had
And lackey by him, gainst all womanhead?
Her dried dugs, like bladders lacking wind,
But fierce Pyrrochles, lacking his owne sword,
Whose presence I haue lackt too long a day;
Till him the child bespoke, Long lackt, alas,
I long haue lackt, I ioy thy face to vew;
Through her dispiteous pride, whilest loue lackt place,
Whereof she long had lackt the wishfull sight,
And by her in a line a milke white lambe she lad.
For griefe whereof the lad n'ould after ioy,
As in their mistresse reskew, whom they lad;
And therewith shot an arrow at the lad;
Or that same daintie lad, which was so deare
That from thenceforth a wretched life they lad,
In all his life, which afterwards he lad,
So home with her she streight the virgin lad,
That lim he could not wag. Thence he him lad,
Whom they by slights allur'd, and to their purpose lad.
Mongst which this lucklesse mayd away was lad,
And many yron bands on him to lade.
And his broad braunches, laden with rich fee,
Laden from far with precious merchandize,
A louely Ladie rode him faire beside,
Be well aware, quoth then that Ladie milde,
Ah Ladie (said he) shame were to reuoke
His Ladie seeing all, that chaunst, from farre
Yet she most faithfull Ladie all this while
Face of faire Ladie she before did vew,
If that of such a Ladie she could tellen ought.
And after for that Ladie did inquere;
Soone as the Faerie heard his Ladie speake,
That euer Ladie to her loue did chose,
He wofull Ladie, wofull Vna met,
Was neuer Ladie loued dearer day,
When as this knight nigh to the Ladie drew,
Ah Ladie deare, quoth then the gentle knight,
But wofull Ladie let me you intrete,
From loftie steede, and bad the Ladie stay,
He lou'd, as was his lot, a Ladie gent,
Is not enough, that to this Ladie milde
That aged Dame, the Ladie of the place:
Which when his pensiue Ladie saw from farre,
And his deare Ladie, that beheld it all,
And to his Lord and Ladie lowd gan call,
Faire Ladie, through foule sorrow ill bedight,
A gentle Ladie, or her wrong through might:
But now, faire Ladie, comfort to you make,
Now therefore Ladie, rise out of your paine,
A knight had wrought against a Ladie gent;
Which plunged had faire Ladie in so wretched state.
A goodly Ladie clad in hunters weed,
But what art thou, ï¿½ Ladie, which doest raunge
Is this to knight, that Ladie should againe
To loue a Ladie faire of great degree,
And gratious to that Ladie, as to mee,
That I that Ladie to my spouse had wonne;
That Ladie whom I had to me assynd,
And therein sate a Ladie fresh and faire,
The lilly, Ladie of the flowring field,
That gentle Ladie did to him impart,
Crying, Let be that Ladie debonaire,
If euer loue of Ladie did empierce
Till that great Ladie thence away them sought,
He lou'd faire Ladie Estrild, lewdly lou'd,
The noble virgin, Ladie of the place,
Of many a Ladie, and many a Paramowre:
That wanton Ladie, with her louer lose,
A goodly Ladie did foreby them rush,
For knight to leaue his Ladie were great shame,
Within this castle wall a Ladie faire,
In case he haue no Ladie, nor no loue,
But if he haue a Ladie or a Loue,
During which worke the Ladie of the Lake,
On a faire Ladie Nonne, that whilome hight
That fearefull Ladie fled from him, that ment
Villein (said he) this Ladie is my deare,
And fain'd to cheare his Ladie in dismay;
Him to poursew, but to the Ladie rode,
The whiles the pitteous Ladie vp did ryse,
To be his Leman and his Ladie trew:
He did resemble to his Ladie bright;
What Ladie, man? (said Trompart) take good hart,
And for a Ladie gainst a faithlesse knight;
Saue that same woefull Ladie, both whose hands
And eke the Ladie selfe he brought away,
And there the Ladie ill of friends bestedded,
A Ladie, seeming in so farre a space,
That had a goodly Ladie by his side,
Where is my part then of this Ladie bright,
Seest not the Ladie there before thy face?
That for this Ladie present in your vew,
Shall to that fairest Ladie be prefard.
That was the learnedst Ladie in her dayes,
And therein sate a Ladie passing faire
Sith each of them his Ladie had him by,
Thrise happie Ladie, and thrise happie knight,
The fayrest Ladie was adiudgd for Paramore.
Let neuer Ladie to his loue assent,
The fayrest Ladie reft, and euer since withheld.
Which secret fate hath in this Ladie wrought,
And you faire Ladie knight, my dearest Dame,
For she deare Ladie all the way was dead,
That lou'd a Ladie of high parentage;
Or loue of fairest Ladie could constraine.
Had not the Ladie with her powrefull speach
But that same Ladie which me friended late
Left a fayre Ladie languishing in payne:
An headlesse Ladie lying him beside,
This lucklesse Ladie, which now here doth headlesse lie.
Which when his Ladie saw, she follow'd fast,
That his false Ladie, as ye heard afore.
Much did his words the gentle Ladie quell,
As for this Ladie, which he sheweth here,
So forth the noble Ladie was ybrought,
Say on my souerayne Ladie, and be bold;
One day her Ladie, calling her apart,
That both her Ladie, and her selfe withall,
Which when his Ladie from the castles hight
With her, to see her Ladie thence no farre away.
To see her Ladie, as they did agree.
So did this mightie Ladie, when she saw
A Ladie of great countenance and place,
He gan that Ladie strongly to appele
Of that great Ladie, who with goodly chere
A Ladie of great worth and wealth had beene,
Within the land, where dwelt that Ladie sad,
Nathlesse (said he) deare Ladie with me goe,
The Ladie counseld him the place to shonne,
At last they came whereas that Ladie bode,
To so faire Ladie, as ye seeme in sight,
Much was the Ladie in her gentle mind
Or for a Ladie, whom a knight should loue,
And them beside a Ladie faire he saw,
For not I him, as this his Ladie here
Together with this Ladie, passing on the plaine.
And this his Ladie, (that him ill became,)
Towards a Ladie, whom with vsage kind
Of that same Ladie, whether what he spoke,
Please it you Ladie, to vs to aread,
Within a wood, whereas a Ladie gent
Faire was the Ladie sure, that mote content
Meane while his Ladie, which this outrage saw,
But since this Ladie is all desolate,
He tooke that Ladie, and her vp did rayse
His wofull Ladie, piteously complayning
Then speaking to the Ladie, thus he sayd:
The Ladie hearing his so courteous speach,
A Ladie on rough waues, row'd in a sommer barge.
And his sad Ladie left in pitifull affright.
And eke the Ladie fearefully aghast,
The Ladie hearkning to his sensefull speach,
And leauing there this Ladie all dismayd,
A saluage man matcht with a Ladie fayre,
Which when the Ladie saw, with great affright
Yet since thy life vnto this Ladie fayre
Atwene that Ladie myld and recreant knight,
Sitting beside his Ladie there at ease,
Had doen to him, and his deare Ladie shent:
But turne we now backe to that Ladie free,
She was a Ladie of great dignitie,
Whylest she, the Ladie of her libertie,
From them returning to that Ladie backe,
In bloudy battell for a Ladie deare,
The fayrest Ladie then of all that liuing were.
And sing of Knights and Ladies gentle deeds;
With bowres, and beds, and Ladies deare delight:
And hope to winne his Ladies heart that day,
The Fort, that Ladies hold in soueraigne dread.
So doubly lou'd of Ladies vnlike faire,
Of Lordes and Ladies stood on euery side
Her Lordes and Ladies all this while deuise
Vnseemely man to please faire Ladies eye;
Yet he of Ladies oft was loued deare,
Old loues, and warres for Ladies doen by many a Lord.
Tho mou'd with wrath, and shame, and Ladies sake,
But Ladies loue as losse of time forbore:
Fell from high Princes courts, or Ladies bowres,
And euer lou'd to fight for Ladies right,
Then serue his Ladies loue, and wast in pleasures vayne.
O hold thy mortall hand for Ladies sake,
Shapt like a Ladies head, exceeding shone,
Next to that Ladies loue, shalbe the place,
On which the thrise three learned Ladies play
And Ladies loue to leaue so dearely bought?
Possessed of his Ladies hart and hand,
Which to these Ladies loue did countenaunce,
He now this Ladies champion chose for loue to fight.
Both knights and Ladies forth right angry far'd,
All for their Ladies froward loue to gaine,
Vnworthy of faire Ladies comely gouernaunce.
Mingled emongst loose Ladies and lasciuious boyes.
That here in Ladies lap entombed art,
Ne Ladies loues, ne sweete entreaties might
What meant that preace about that Ladies throne,
For which th'IdÃ¦an Ladies disagreed,
The whiles the other Ladies mind their merry glee.
Beare ye the picture of that Ladies head?
Came to the Ladies eare, which there did dwell,
Of Squires and Ladies equipaged well,
A louely beuy of faire Ladies sate,
They were faire Ladies, till they fondly striu'd
Many faire Ladies, and lasciuious boyes,
That to all Ladies, which haue it profest,
Ne reckt of Ladies Loue, did stay behind,
(Said they) and haue our Ladies loue for his reward.
Faire Ladies, and of many a gentle knight,
Eftsoones them brought vnto their Ladies sight,
Thence they were brought to that great Ladies vew,
Faire Ladies, that to loue captiued arre,
And those six Knights that Ladies Champions,
Was vsd of Knights and Ladies seeming gent:
As Ladies wont, in pleasures wanton lap,
Do many famous Knightes and Ladies wonne,
Defending Ladies cause, and Orphans right,
Old Glauce cast, to cure this Ladies griefe:
In the meane time through that false Ladies traine,
And euer from faire Ladies loue did fly;
Yet many Ladies faire did oft complaine,
That Ladies loue vnto his Lord forlent,
For Ladies loue his mother long ygoe
And honour of trew Ladies, if ye may
Of all good Ladies through the world so wide,
Ill weares he armes, that nill them vse for Ladies sake.
Of life, whom late their Ladies arrow ryu'd:
In gentle Ladies brest, and bounteous race
That Ladies all may follow her ensample dead.
Well may I weene, faire Ladies, all this while
Ladies and Lords she euery where mote heare
To all faire Ladies, that doe liue on ground.
Fraile Ladies hart with loues consuming rage,
So well I to faire Ladies seruice did,
My Ladies loue, in such a desperate case,
Seeking to match the chaste with th'vnchaste Ladies traine.
O ye braue knights, that boast this Ladies loue,
The which himselfe, then Ladies more defames,
And all faire Ladies may for euer sory be.
That Ladies safetie is sore to be drad:
Vnfit faire Ladies seruice to supply;
That madest many Ladies deare lament
But for faire Ladies loue, and glories gaine,
Of knights and ladies any meetings were,
And all faire Ladies magnifie your might,
And ye faire Ladies, that your kingdomes make
As gentle Ladies helplesse misery.
Ah, how the fearefull Ladies tender hart
Kings Queenes, Lords Ladies, Knights & Damzels gent
She claim'd that to her selfe, as Ladies det,
Such when those Knights and Ladies all about
But Ladies none they were, albee in face
Ne for light Ladies loue, that soone is lost.
Why do ye striue for Ladies loue so sore,
Loathed of ladies all, and of all knights defyde.
But that in all those knights and ladies sight,
And that which is for Ladies most befitting,
And rather die then Ladies cause release.
And first laide on those Ladies thousand blames,
That lost faire Ladies ornament should weare,
To which all knights with them their Ladies are to bring.
To weete, two Ladies of most goodly hew,
And those two Ladies their two louers deare,
Then life to hazard for faire Ladies looke;
So cruelly these Knights stroue for that Ladies sake.
And eke those masked Ladies riding them beside.
And those two Ladies, their two loues vnseene;
To Ladies loue, where so he came in place,
Braue Knights and Ladies, certes ye doe wrong
The knights in couples marcht, with ladies linckt attone.
The Ladies for the Girdle striue
Which Ladies ought to loue, and seeke for to obtaine.
So many Ladies sought, as shall appeare;
And after these an hundred Ladies moe
Then many other Ladies likewise tride,
Thereat all Knights gan laugh, and Ladies lowre:
And now become to liue a Ladies thrall,
In feeble Ladies tyranning so sore;
By any Ladies side for Leman to haue laine.
Led with that wofull Ladies piteous crying,
In which his Ladies colours were, did bind
He chaunst to come where those two Ladies late,
The euill case in which those Ladies lay;
These gentle Ladies will misdeeme too light,
The Ladies both on horse, together fast embraced.
That those two Ladies much asham'd did wexe:
Eftsoones the Prince tooke downe those Ladies twaine
To come forthwith vnto his Ladies bowre.
Those Ladies two yet doubtfull through dismay
Those weaker Ladies after weary toile;
And vnto Ladies loue would lend no leasure:
And eke the loue of Ladies foule defame;
For that faire Ladies loue: past perils well apay.
Then hearke ye gentle knights and Ladies free,
Which Ladies loue I heard had neuer wonne
How she that Ladies libertie might enterprize.
His Ladies bloud embrewed.
That did his hand in Ladies bloud embrew,
So did the Ladies both, as may be knowne,
For neither he did shed that Ladies bloud,
Beare for his penaunce that same Ladies head;
He chose with shame to beare that Ladies head
Your owne dead Ladies head, to tell abrode your shame.
To beare that Ladies head before his breast.
in all the Ladies sights.
Of Lords and Ladies infinite great store;
The pride of Ladies, and the worth of knights,
For her, but for his owne deare Ladies sake,
So did this Ladies goodly forme decay,
Full many Ladies often had assayd,
